article_title: Staying Ahead Of NJ's Organized Delivery Systems
article_text:
Staying Ahead Of NJ's Organized Delivery Systems

Law360, New York (June 15, 2015, 2:37 PM ET) -- New Jersey law has created a unique regulatory status for any entity contracting with a health insurance carrier or other type of health plan for the provision of health care services, but which is not itself a licensed provider such as a hospital or physician group or an actual insurer or plan. Such entities, broadly referred to as Organized Delivery Systems (ODSs), are subject to regulation by the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance (DOBI). An entity which bears financial risk for the provision of...

To view the full article, register now.

article_metadata.description: As the collaborative care model and provider responsibility for patient outcomes becomes more embedded in the New Jersey health care marketplace, many health care provider networks and utilization review entities may conclude that the ability to offer risk-bearing arrangements — and hence obtaining organized delivery system licensure — is critical to growing their business in the state, say Michael Morris and Cynthia Borrelli of Bressler Amery & Ross PC.
